name: NPR
text:
Russia has rejected any blame for the poisoning of Putin critic Alexei Navalny, but a former CIA official says "this is something that the Russian intelligence services have been doing literally for decades, if not longer."
https://t.co/3SM5gwzhRA

name: NPR
text:
RT @BobbyAllyn: Trump's order banning TikTok could make 4,000 freelance teachers in the U.S. lose their jobs, or worse.

One instructor told me: "I could be put in jail for teaching a five-year-old how to say hello from across the computer."

https://t.co/qx7u6Mbe6s

name: NPR
text: Flu season is just around the corner in the Northern Hemisphere — and now there's the coronavirus pandemic, too. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, what lessons can we learn from countries in the Southern Hemisphere where the same thing just happened? https://t.co/ab7b2HvP8r

name: NPR
text:
The start of a school year is prime time for registering college students to vote — and amid the pandemic, mobilization efforts are going virtual.

But campus organizers warn digital tools cannot fully replace face-to-face interaction.
https://t.co/m0Lp8o9p4y

name: NPR
text: The suspect in the fatal shooting of a far-right protester in Portland, Oregon last weekend, was killed by law enforcement attempting to arrest him. In an interview published hours earlier, he said the shooting was an act of self defense. https://t.co/dYhC7V4OJD

name: NPR
text:
Within days of George Floyd's death, prominent Black musicians across a variety of genres began to release songs that expressed grief, rage, exhaustion and resolution in the face of America's 400-year history of institutional racism.
https://t.co/JRuBniqYVx

name: NPR
text:
In “Having and Being Had,” author Eula Biss captures the American value system of buying and owning — and what we trap ourselves in when we invest in the trappings of the middle class.
https://t.co/bXeCqb5WN5

name: NPR
text: From the creation of the first penitentiaries in the 1800s to the "tough-on-crime" prosecutors of the 1990s, a look at how America created a culture of mass incarceration. https://t.co/OrbW41gfvq

name: NPR
text:
Burt Bacharach is a legend in the world of popular music and he’s still performing at age 92 — as you'll see in this Tiny Desk quarantine concert with lyricist Daniel Tashian.
https://t.co/VDindyDRZt

name: NPR
text:
Spinning a Chinese legend into family-friendly entertainment with worldwide appeal is tricky. The new "Mulan" is a watered-down version of a potentially captivating story, our reviewer writes.
https://t.co/vqVUip7VpX

name: NPR
text: Robo-graders have drawn criticism from experts who say they can be biased against certain demographic groups, and from teachers who point out the absurdity of grading writing by machine. (@wbur) https://t.co/xsOCo3lQLc

name: NPR
text:
There's a lot that scientists don't know about how viral infections can interact. 

But researchers are eager to figure out how coronavirus infections might affect flu infections — and vice versa.
https://t.co/b4N36WLqL5

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: R&B star @sza is back with "Hit Different," featuring @tydollasign  and production by @TheNeptunes.  https://t.co/YgLKJyVF9f https://t.co/fDNhv7IeLG
